ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Understanding of international monetary system. Able to answer questions like why US bonds enjoy such a low interests.
An understand of current research relating to international monetary systems

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strength: Well structured, deep content, engaging lectures 
Weakness: only meet once a week
I enjoy that it was open ended and allowed us to write and present our own paper instead of a final.
giving out deadlines on the syllabus at the beginning of the semester would be helpful, but not necessary

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. This is one of the few econ courses I have taken at Yale that focuses almost exclusively on the cutting edge of research in the field, making it truly engaging and fascinating
Yes. I would recommend the class to another student who is interested in understanding global monetary system.
it was really technical, so without a strong background in international trade/statistics I oftentimes was a bit lost
